topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Jackson and Lenny frame Duolingo streaks as a major growth/retention lever, previewing a deep-dive episode format focused on one feature and its learnings.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor messages for Pendo and Vanta.

topics.title: What streaks are and why they matter
topics.summary: Jackson explains what the streak feature is (including streak freezes) and why it’s so impactful, including its role in notifications and habit formation.

topics.title: Origins: XP-based streaks to one-lesson streaks
topics.summary: Jackson recounts the original XP-based goal system and the pivotal shift to a simpler “one lesson per day” streak, emphasizing choosing the right unit of use.

topics.title: Engagement vs learning: the Duolingo philosophy
topics.summary: They discuss Duolingo’s stance that engagement enables learning, plus the risk of over-optimizing engagement in ways that could undermine real learning value.

topics.title: Testing extremes and building experimentation muscle
topics.summary: Jackson shares an experiment that made streaks even easier (one exercise) that didn’t move DAUs, and explains Duolingo’s high-velocity approach: 600+ streak experiments.

topics.title: Experiment decision-making: neutral results and complexity
topics.summary: They cover how Duolingo treats neutral experiments (often shut down to avoid cognitive load) and when a neutral change might ship as a platform for future wins.

topics.title: Optimizing the first week: loss aversion threshold
topics.summary: Jackson explains why Duolingo focuses heavily on getting users to a 7-day streak, where loss aversion kicks in and retention gains flatten beyond that point.

topics.title: Streak goals: commitment, optionality, and friction
topics.summary: They walk through the evolution of streak goal-setting experiments: outcome framing, testing different goal lengths, adding opt-out, and learning that user choice drives commitment.

topics.title: Mining for wins: hypotheses, cross-team learnings, copy tests
topics.summary: Jackson describes how Duolingo forms strong hypotheses (often borrowing from monetization and games), invests in copy-testing infrastructure, and cites a big CTA win (“Commit to my goal”).

topics.title: Avoiding a Frankenstein product: reviews and resets
topics.summary: They discuss risks of constant experimentation creating incoherence, and how Duolingo mitigates it via founder-led product review, quarterly strategy checks, and occasional UI resets.

topics.title: Why streaks work: meaning, framing, long-term progress
topics.summary: Jackson explains Duolingo’s advantage (a meaningful goal) and how other apps can reframe streaks; he also notes streaks help make slow, long-term progress feel tangible.

topics.title: Clarity drives retention: explaining streak mechanics
topics.summary: They cover how many users don’t understand streaks or streak freezes, and how simple explanatory copy at streak start produced a large retention/DAU win; Jackson also notes CURR as a key metric.

topics.title: When a winning experiment shouldn’t ship
topics.summary: Jackson shares an example where showing XP during lessons improved metrics but was rejected to protect the learning-focused lesson experience and avoid distracting UI creep.

topics.title: Design and cultural considerations: flame vs number
topics.summary: Jackson discusses the streak flame metaphor not resonating in some cultures, and how redesigns emphasized the streak number and calendar-like visuals to improve comprehension without losing delight.
